title: iMessage History: The Scapegoat & Family Coalition
description: Text messages showing entrenched scapegoating pattern and family coalition against protagonist

message_history.message: Hey Kate, just wanted to give you a heads up that I can't make Thanksgiving this year. Work scheduled me for a project deadline that week.
Of course you're bailing. Why am I not surprised?
I'm not bailing, I have a work obligation. I didn't choose this timing.
You always have an excuse. Family is never a priority for you.
That's not fair. I've been to every family event for the past 2 years. You missed Mom's birthday party last month and no one said anything.
I had a valid reason. That's different.
How is it different? We both have work obligations.
Because YOU have a pattern of letting this family down. Everyone knows it.
Mom, you're not going to believe this. [You] is bailing on Thanksgiving. Again.
Are you serious? After last year?
Dead serious. Some 'work thing'. I'm so tired of their excuses.
I'm so disappointed. This is typical behavior.
Kate told me you're not coming to Thanksgiving. I'm very hurt by this.
Mom, I have a mandatory work deadline. I tried to get out of it but couldn't. I'm sorry.
There's always something with you. Your sister manages to make time for family.
Kate missed your birthday party last month and you said that was fine.
That was completely different. She had a medical issue. You're choosing work over family.
I'm not CHOOSING anything. I have an obligation I can't get out of. Why is it okay when she misses something but not me?
Because she doesn't have a PATTERN of this behavior. You do. Everyone in this family sees it.
Mom, I've been thinking about what you said. Can we talk about this 'pattern' you mentioned? I genuinely don't understand what you mean.
There's nothing to discuss. You know what you've done over the years.
But I don't know. Can you give me specific examples? I want to understand.
You've always been difficult. Since you were young. Your father and I have tried our best but you've always pushed back.
I'm asking for specific things I've done. What have I pushed back on?
Your sister and I were just talking about how you make everything about you. Even now, you're doing it.
You and Kate were talking about me? What did you say?
We both agree that you've been the source of a lot of family tension over the years.
Tom, has Mom talked to you about me lately?
Yeah, she mentioned the Thanksgiving thing. Sounds complicated.
Did she say anything else? Like that I'm the 'source of family tension'?
Look, I try to stay out of this stuff. But yeah, Mom and Kate think you're... I don't know, more difficult than the rest of us.
What do YOU think? Do you think I'm the problem?
Honestly? I think you ask too many questions. Sometimes it's better to just let things go. That's what I do.
But do you think I'M the reason for family problems? Am I really that bad?
I don't think you're bad. But you do kind of rock the boat a lot. Mom and Kate wouldn't say this stuff if there wasn't some truth to it.
Mom, I've been feeling really hurt by what you and Kate have been saying about me. Can we please talk about this?
I'm not going to apologize for being honest. You've caused problems in this family for years.
What problems? Please give me ONE specific example.
The fact that you're even asking proves my point. You don't see how your behavior affects others.
How can I change if no one will tell me what I'm doing wrong?
Maybe you can't change. Maybe this is just who you are.
Mom told me you're harassing her about this. Can you just leave her alone?
I'm not harassing anyone. I'm trying to understand why everyone thinks I'm the problem.
This is EXACTLY what we're talking about. You're exhausting. You make everything so difficult.
Kate, I genuinely don't understand. What am I doing that's so wrong?
You're doing it RIGHT NOW. Making this all about you. Mom is upset, and instead of apologizing, you're demanding explanations.
I just want to understand what I'm apologizing FOR.
The fact that you don't already know is the problem. Mom and I are done with this conversation.
Mom, I really need to talk to you about all of this. Can I call you? Please?
Fine. But I don't know what you expect to accomplish. Your father and I have made peace with who you are.

context_notes.scapegoat_pattern: Protagonist held to different standard than sister → Any questioning labeled as 'difficult' → Family coalition agrees protagonist is 'the problem'
context_notes.circular_logic: Protagonist can't get specific examples of bad behavior → Asking for examples is framed as proof of bad behavior
context_notes.family_narrative: 'You've always been difficult', 'That's just who you are', 'Everyone sees it'
context_notes.coalition: Mom and Kate explicitly discuss protagonist negatively → Brother passively agrees with family narrative
context_notes.protagonist_state: Desperate to understand what they're doing wrong → Beginning to internalize shame → Questioning own reality
context_notes.emotional_exhaustion: Repeatedly asking for clarity → Being told asking itself is the problem
context_notes.triggering_realization: The family has 'made peace with who you are' = They've decided protagonist is permanently the problem

roleplay_entry_point: Phone call with Mom where protagonist needs to navigate between seeking understanding and accepting this dynamic may never change.
